text: Hello! I'm happy to help you assess your risk for developing type 2 diabetes. According to the American Diabetes Association (ADA), there are several factors that can increase your likelihood of developing this condition. Please keep in mind that these are general guidelines and it is always best to consult with a healthcare professional for personalized advice. Risk Factors for Type 2 Diabetes: 1. Age: The risk of developing type 2 diabetes increases with age, especially after the age of 45. 2. Obesity: Being overweight or obese is a significant risk factor for type 2 diabetes. Excess body fat can lead to insulin resistance, which makes it harder for your body to use insulin effectively. 3. Physical Inactivity: A sedentary lifestyle can also contribute to the development of type 2 diabetes. Regular physical activity helps improve insulin sensitivity and glucose uptake in the muscles. 4. Family History: Having a first-degree relative (such as a parent or sibling) with type 2 diabetes increases your risk of developing the condition. 5. Previous Gestational Diabetes: If you have had gestational diabetes during pregnancy, you are at increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes later in life. 6. High Blood Pressure: Hypertension (high blood pressure) can damage blood vessels and organs, increasing the risk of complications from type 2 diabetes. 7. High Cholesterol: Elevated cholesterol levels can contribute to the development of insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes. 8. Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): Women with PCOS are at higher risk of developing insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes. 9. Sleep Apnea: This sleep disorder can increase the risk of developing type 2 diabetes by contributing to inflammation and metabolic dysregulation. 10. Certain Medications: Some medications, such as steroids and certain antipsychotic drugs, can increase the risk of developing type 2 diabetes. Your risk for developing type 2 diabetes can be influenced by various lifestyle and medical factors. Some common risk factors include being overweight or obese, having a family history of diabetes, physical inactivity, poor diet, and certain medications. It is important to engage in a healthy lifestyle, such as regular physical activity and a balanced diet, to reduce your risk of developing diabetes. Additionally, getting regular check-ups with your healthcare provider can help monitor your risk and ensure early detection and treatment if necessary.

Firstly, it is essential to comprehend that Type 2 diabetes is a chronic condition characterized by high blood sugar levels due to insulin resistance or an inability to produce sufficient amounts of insulin. The primary cause of Type 2 diabetes is obesity, physical inactivity, genetics, age, ethnicity, and history of gestational diabetes (during pregnancy). To determine your personal risk factors for developing Type 2 diabetes, let us consider the following points: 1. Age: Your chance of acquiring Type 2 diabetes rises after the age of 45. However, if you have a family history or other variables such as excess weight or high blood pressure, this may begin sooner. 2. Weight and body mass index (BMI): Being overweight or having central adiposity increases the likelihood of getting Type 2 diabetes. A BMI higher than 30 puts you at greater danger. 3. Physical activity level: If you lead an inactive lifestyle, you run a higher chance of growing Type 2 diabetes. Even modest exercise like walking can aid in reducing the risk. 4. Family history: Having firsthand relatives with Type 2 diabetes raises your risk of acquiring the disease. If several close relatives have been diagnosed, your chances rise even more. 5. Ethnicity/race: People from particular races and cultures are at a higher risk of acquiring Type 2 diabetes, including African Americans, Hispanics, Native Americans, Pacific Islanders, and Asian Americans. 6. Hypertension and high blood pressure: Have you previously been told you have hypertension? High blood pressure raises your possibility of acquiring Type 2 diabetes, along with heart illnesses. 7. Previous history of gestational diabetes: Women who have had gestational diabetes during their pregnancies are more likely to develop Type 2 diabetes later in life. 8. Your risk for developing type 2 diabetes can be influenced by several factors. Some of the main risk factors include: 1. Weight: Being overweight or obese increases your risk for type 2 diabetes. This is because excess body fat can make it harder for your body to use insulin effectively. 2. Physical activity: Lack of regular physical activity can contribute to the development of type 2 diabetes. Engaging in regular exercise helps your body use insulin more efficiently and can lower your risk. 3. Family history: Having a close family member with type 2 diabetes increases your risk. This suggests that there may be a genetic component involved in developing the condition. 4. Age: The risk of developing type 2 diabetes increases with age, especially after the age of 45. This is thought to be due to a combination of factors, including decreased physical activity and changes in hormone levels. 5. Ethnicity: Certain ethnic groups, such as African Americans, Hispanic/Latino Americans, Native Americans, Asian Americans, and Pacific Islanders, have a higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes compared to other populations. 6. Gestational diabetes: If you had gestational diabetes during pregnancy, you are at increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes later in life. Additionally, if you gave birth to a baby weighing over 9 pounds, you may also have a higher risk. 7. Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS): Women with PCOS have a higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes. PCOS is a hormonal disorder that affects the ovaries and can lead to insulin resistance. It's important to note that having these risk factors does not mean you will definitely develop type 2 diabetes. However, being aware of your risk factors can help you make informed lifestyle choices to reduce your risk. If you are concerned about your risk for type 2 diabetes, it is recommended to consult with your healthcare provider who can evaluate your individual risk factors and provide personalized advice.

Your risk for developing Type 2 Diabetes is 50% or more if you smoke, drink alcohol, eat too many fat foods, have high blood pressure, or are overweight. You are at lower risk if you follow dietary guidelines that reduce your consumption of saturated fats and cholesterol and decrease the amount of red meat in your diet. In addition, you may be at higher risk for Type 2 Diabetes if you are over age 35 years old (2). How can I minimize my risk for type 2 diabetes? Complete Answer: To avoid having a negative impact on your future health, it is important to maintain a healthy weight and to exercise regularly. Type 2 diabetes develops when your body's cells are unable to take in and process the insulin your pancreas produces. You develop what is called "insulin resistance." In some cases, your body may not be able to produce enough insulin to get the needed glucose into your cells. People who have the following medical conditions are also more likely to develop type 2 diabetes: (Hypertension). People who have consistent readings of 140/90 mm Hg or higher. Women with this disorder have problems that may include infertility, lack of menstrual periods, obesity and insulin resistance. Genetics plays a major role in type 2 diabetes. Having a parent or sibling with diabetes is one of the strongest risk factors. However, you must also have environmental risk factors. People who have strong family histories without environmental factors may not develop the disease. Some of the environmental triggers for type 2 diabetes include: High-fat, high-calorie diets and little exercise contribute to obesity, one of the strongest triggers for developing type 2 diabetes. About 80 percent of people who have type 2 diabetes are overweight. The risk of diabetes due to obesity increases among children and people who have been overweight for a long period of time. People in the U.S. and Europe who eat a Westernized diet that is high in fat and low in fiber often develop type 2 diabetes. People who spend more time sitting than moving and who get little exercise are more apt to develop type 2 diabetes. Several risk factors have been associated with and include: *Impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) is a category of higher than normal blood glucose, but below the threshold for diagnosing diabetes. Changes in diet and physical activity related to rapid development and urbanisation have led to sharp increases in the numbers of people developing diabetes. Pregnant women who are overweight, have been diagnosed with IGT, or have a family history of diabetes are all at increased risk of developing gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). In addition, having been previously diagnosed with gestational diabetes or being of certain ethnic groups puts women at increased risk of developing GDM. Brief questionnaires are simple, practical and inexpensive ways to quickly identify people who may be at a higher risk of type 2 diabetes and who need to have their level of risk further investigated. The , developed in 2001, is an example of an effective questionnaire that can be used as the basis for developing national questionnaires which take into account local factors. It has eight scored questions, with the total test score providing a measure of the probability of developing type 2 diabetes over the following 10 years. The reverse of the form contains brief advice on what the respondent can do to lower their risk of developing the disease, and whether they should seek advice or have a clinical examination. The test takes only a couple of minutes to complete and can be done online, in pharmacies or at various public campaign events. IDF has developed an IDF type 2 diabetes online diabetes risk assessment which aims to predict an individual’s risk of developing type 2 diabetes within the next ten years. The test is based on the Finnish Diabetes Risk Score (FINDRISC) developed and designed by Adj. It represents the interests of the growing number of people with diabetes and those at risk. The Federation has been leading the global diabetes community since 1950. ©2018 WebMD, Inc. All rights reserved. eMedicineHealth does not provide medical advice, diagnosis or treatment. Reviewed By: Type 2 diabetes can affect all people, regardless of age. Early symptoms of type 2 diabetes may be missed, so those affected may not even know they have the condition. An estimated one out of every three people within the early stages of type 2 diabetes are not aware they have it. Diabetes interferes with the body's ability to metabolize carbohydrates for energy, leading to high levels of blood sugar. These chronically high blood sugar levels increase a person's risk of developing serious health problems. Over the long term, potential consequences of untreated high blood sugar include: Although people with type 2 diabetes may not have specific symptoms, an increase in thirst is one symptom that is characteristic of the condition. The increased thirst can accompany other symptoms like frequent urination, feelings of unusual hunger, dry mouth, and weight gain or loss. Other symptoms that can occur if high blood sugar levels persist are fatigue, blurred vision, and headaches. Often, type 2 diabetes is only identified after its negative health consequences are apparent. Certain infections and sores that take a long time to heal are a warning sign. Other possible signs include frequent yeast infections, urinary tract infections, and itchy skin. Sexual problems can occur as a result of type 2 diabetes. Since diabetes can damage the blood vessels and nerves in the sex organs, decreased sensation can develop, potentially leading to difficulties with orgasm. Vaginal dryness in women and impotence in men are other complications of diabetes. Estimates suggest that between 35% and 70% of men with diabetes will eventually suffer from impotence. Statistics for women show that about one-third of women with diabetes will have some sexual dysfunction. Certain risk factors related to both lifestyle choices and medical conditions can increase your risk of developing type 2 diabetes. These include: Being overweight or obese, especially around the waist Consuming a diet that is high in processed meat, fat, sweets, and red meats Low levels of “good” HDL cholesterol (below 35 mg/dL) Some risk factors for diabetes can't be controlled. Hispanics, Native Americans, Asians, and African Americans have a higher than average risk for getting diabetes. Having a family history (parent or sibling) with diabetes increases your risk. Those over 45 have a higher risk of type 2 diabetes than younger people. Women who developed gestational diabetes in pregnancy have a higher risk for developing type 2 diabetes later in life. The same goes for women who have babies larger than 9 pounds. Polycystic ovary syndrome is a health problem characterized by many small cysts in the ovaries, irregular periods, and high levels of androgen hormones. Because one symptom of polycystic ovary syndrome is insulin resistance, women with this condition are considered at higher risk for diabetes as well. Insulin is a hormone that allows the body to efficiently use glucose as fuel. By Laura Hieronymus, MSEd, RN, MLDE, BC-ADM, CDE, FAADE, and Gena Teutsch Miller, MD Diabetes affects 29.1 million Americans, or 9.3% of the U.S. population — and of all people with diabetes, about 95% have Type 2[1]. When you live with Type 2 diabetes, you quickly realize that your immediate family lives with it, too. Family support is essential when it comes to day-to-day management of diabetes and avoiding serious health issues related to the disease. Diabetes can affect the entire family in several ways. In particular, your blood relatives should be aware that a family history of Type 2 diabetes puts them at higher risk for developing both Type 2 and prediabetes[2]. Prediabetes is diagnosed when blood glucose is higher than normal but not high enough for a diagnosis of diabetes; it’s a risk factor for the development of Type 2 diabetes. It is well documented that Type 2 diabetes runs in families. If you have it, your family members — especially close relatives such as siblings and children — have a strong genetic tendency to develop the disease. Your children’s risk of developing diabetes correlates with the age at which you were diagnosed. If you were diagnosed before age 50, your offspring have a one in seven chance of developing Type 2 diabetes; if you were diagnosed after age 50, the possibility drops to one in 13. Some research suggests that a child’s risk for developing Type 2 diabetes increases if the parent with Type 2 is the mother, and that the risk goes up to about 50% if both parents have it. If you’re an identical twin with Type 2 diabetes, your twin’s risk is almost three in four. In fact, if you have Type 2 diabetes but can’t think of any relatives who have it, chances are that some do have it but don’t know it yet. Currently, almost 30% of people with Type 2 diabetes are unaware they have it, and 51% of people aged 65 years or older have prediabetes. The risk for Type 2 diabetes is also higher if your family is of Asian American, African American, Native American, Alaskan native, or Hispanic descent. Gestational diabetes[3] occurs during pregnancy and usually disappears once the baby is delivered. A family history of Type 2 diabetes raises the risk of developing gestational diabetes, and having gestational diabetes significantly raises a woman’s risk of developing Type 2 diabetes later in life. If you have Type 2 diabetes and have a daughter of childbearing age who is considering pregnancy, be sure she is aware of these risks. In addition, when a woman has a history of gestational diabetes, her child’s risk of developing Type 2 diabetes increases. You can be an advocate for your family members by discussing and addressing their higher risk for Type 2 diabetes, prediabetes, and gestational diabetes. Genetics and ethnicity cannot be changed, but being aware of these risk factors can encourage your family members to attend to any modifiable risks they may have, and sooner rather than later. The likelihood of developing type 2 diabetes increases as your age, gender, body mass index, smoking history, education level, physical activity level, family history of diabetes (including gestational diabetes), family history of heart disease, and other factors increase. Risk for developing type 2 diabetes is greater in women than men. However, both genders have an increased risk if they smoke or consume alcohol.\ nQuestion: My risk for developing high blood pressure
Answer: You have a higher risk for developing hypertension if you're obese and/or heavy smoker. Women are at a lower risk for developing hypertension than men; however, women who've had gestational diabetes may be more vulnerable to developing hypertension. In addition, being overweight or obese increases your risk of developing hypertension by up to 25%. 
Question: Can I lose weight without losing muscle?\ Answer: No. Weight loss can cause changes in muscle, including decreases in strength, size, and ability to perform activities of daily living. Some people do achieve a permanent reduction in body fat percentage, but it takes time and requires consistent effort over a long period of time. People who want to become lighter should start with healthy diet and exercise practices first. Follow these guidelines to help keep your waistline under control: 
Eat a healthy, balanced diet that includes fruits, vegetables, whole grains, legumes, low-fat dairy products, lean meats and poultry, fish, nuts and seeds, olive oil, avocados, soy products, beans, and low-sodium foods. Limit saturated fats from animal sources, trans fats, partially hydrogenated oils, sugar, refined cereals, sweetened beverages and juices, fried potatoes, and candy. Limit calories. Exercise regularly, especially walking at least 30 minutes each day. Eat breakfast. Eat dinner. Don't skip meals. Be active. Drink plenty of water and take part in the recommended amount of moderate-intensity physical activity (such as brisk walking). Do not use tobacco products. Get enough sleep. Avoid getting too much sun during daylight hours. Keep away from sources of excess heat, such as parked cars, tanning beds, hot tubs, saunas, steam rooms, outdoor BBQ's, etc. Reduce caffeine intake. Take care of your skin. Wear sunscreen. Have regular eye exams.
